Re: ''A Sense of Anxiety a Shirt Won't Cover'' by Alex Kuczynski (Thursday Styles, June 14):
As a plastic surgeon with a subspecialty in gynecomastia, I am dismayed at the tenor of your article.

It is made to appear as if young men with this problem are simply fat or vain and seeking an easy way out. Nothing could be further from the truth. I have operated on more than 1,300 men, including more than 70 adolescent boys, with this problem, and most of them were of normal weight.

Their stories are all remarkably similar: teasing and taunting during teenage years, refraining from sports, reluctance in intimate situations and -- in some cases -- deliberately gaining weight because obesity is unfortunately more tolerated in this country than men with enlarged breasts.

To date, absolutely none of my patients has had a regrowth of breast tissue. And my experience runs contrary to the medical opinions that the problem will disappear just by waiting it out. Too many of my 20-something-year-olds did just that. They waited in vain during their precious adolescence for the problem to resolve itself -- and it didn't.

And it is during these years, when self-esteem, ego and self-confidence are being built, that these boys are teased and retreat into a shell. I have witnessed remarkable changes in these boys' personality once this burden has been literally and figuratively lifted off their chest.
Elliot W. Jacobs, M.D. New York
